Bases: object

Represents an airport’s runway

calc_approach_dimensions()¶

Calculates the dimensions of the approaches at either end of the runway

Return dict[RunwayEnd, dict[str, float]]:

a mapping of the runway’s end to its dimensions

Return type:

dict[RunwayEnd, dict[str, float]]

runway_surfaces.surfaces module¶

class runway_surfaces.surfaces.Arc(center, radius)¶

Bases: Edge

class runway_surfaces.surfaces.Edge(p1, p2, center=())¶

Bases: object

Represents a straight or curved edge of a horizontal surface around a series of runways

runway_surfaces.surfaces.get_approach_surface_vertices(end_infos, psurface_vertices)¶

Gets the vertices of the 2D projection of the approach surface

For each RunwayEnd in end_infos, a list of 4 2D coordinate points is generated that create bounds for the approach surface.

Parameters:

  • end_infos (dict[RunwayEnd, dict[str, float]]) – a mapping of one runway’s ends to their respective dimensions/infos as returned by Runway.calc_approach_dimensions

  • psurface_vertices (dict[RunwayEnd, list[tuple[float, float]]]) – a mapping of one runway’s ends to the vertices of the primary surface of that runway’s end

Return dict[RunwayEnd, list[tuple[float, float]]]:

a mapping of each runway end of one runway to a list of 2D vertices that are the bounds of the respective approach surface

Return type:

dict[RunwayEnd, list[tuple[float, float]]]

runway_surfaces.surfaces.get_horizontal_surface_edges(runways)¶

Gets the outline of the horizontal surface encompassing every runway in runways

See FAR Part-77

Parameters:

runways (list[Runway]) – a list of ``Runway``s

Return list[Edge]:

a list of ``Edge``s defining the outline of the horizontal surface

Return type:

list[Edge]

runway_surfaces.surfaces.get_primary_surface_vertices(runway)¶

Gets the 2D coordinate points of the vertices of the primary surface for runway

Parameters:

runway (Runway) – a runway

Return dict[RunwayEnd, list[tuple[float, float]]]:

the ends of runway mapped to their respective primary surface vertices

Return type:

dict[RunwayEnd, list[tuple[float, float]]]

runway_surfaces.surfaces.get_transitional_surface_vertices(psurface_vertices, asurfaces)¶

Gets the vertices of the 2D projection of the transitional surface

A 2x4 list is returned where the the first row contains all the vertices for the transitional surface on one side of the runway, while the second row contains all the vertices for the transitional surface on the other side of the runway.

Parameters:

  • psurface_vertices (dict[RunwayEnd, list[tuple[float, float]]]) – a mapping of one runway’s ends to the vertices of the primary surface of that runway’s end

  • asurfaces (dict[RunwayEnd, list[tuple[float, float]]]) – a mapping of one runway’s ends to the vertices of the approach surface of that runway’s end

Return list[list[tuple[float, float]]]:

a list containing lists of the vertices of the transitional surface for either side of the runway

Return type:

list[list[tuple[float, float]]]

runway_surfaces.surfaces.get_zone_information(position, runways, eae)¶

Gets the information about the imaginary zone that position is in

Parameters:

  • runways (list[Runway]) – a list of runways

  • position (tuple[float, float, float]) – a 3D coordinate

  • eae (float) – the established airport elevation of the airport containing runways

Return dict[str, str]:

a mapping of info to its value (e.g. "zone": "Transitional Surface")

Return type:

dict[str, str]

runway_surfaces.surfaces.is_in_approach_surface(position, asurface, approach_dimensions, eae)¶

Checks if position is in or on the boundary of an approach surface defined by asurface

Parameters:

  • position (tuple[float, float, float]) – a 3D coordinate point

  • asurface (list[tuple[float, float]]) – a list of 2D vertices bounding the approach surface

  • approach_dimensions (dict[str, float]) – the dimensions of the approach surface as returned by Runway.calc_approach_dimensions

  • eae (float) – the established airport elevation

Return Optional[Callable[[float, float], float]]:

a function that is the equation of a 3D surface in the form of z = f(x,y) bounding position from above

Return type:

Optional[Callable[[float, float], float]]

  • hsurface (list[Edge]) – a list of Edges defining a horizontal surface

  • eae (float) – the established airport elevation

Return type:

Optional[Callable[[float, float], float]]

  • hsurface (list[Edge]) – a list of Edges defining a horizontal surface

  • tsurface (list[tuple[float, float]]) – a list of 2D vertices bounding the transitional surface

  • height (float) – the desired z-value

Return float:

the distance in the 2D plane required to reach height with slope

  • p2 (tuple[float, float]) – a 2D coordinate point

Return float:

the distance between p1 and p2

Return type:

runway_surfaces.util.cet2cr(c1, r1, c2, r2)¶

Gets the common external tangent line on the right side of two circles

Two non-overlapping circles have 4 common tangent lines: 2 external and 2 internal. The external tangent lines do not cross the line passing through each circle’s center, while the internal tangent lines does. When creating a vector going from c1 to c2, there is a right side and a left side. cet2cr translates to “right-side common external tangent of two circles”.

Parameters:

  • c1 (tuple[float, float]) – a 2D centerpoint of a circle

  • r1 (float) – the radius of the circle centered at c1

  • c2 (tuple[float, float]) – a 2D centerpoint of a circle

  • r2 (float) – the radius of the circle centered at c2

Return list[tuple[float, float]]:

a 2D coordinate point on each circle the common tangent line passes through

Return type:

list[tuple[float, float]]

runway_surfaces.util.circle_in_circle(c1, r1, c2, r2)¶

Checks if either circle is completely inside the other

Parameters:

  • c1 (tuple[float, float]) – a 2D centerpoint of a circle

  • r1 (float) – the radius of the circle centered at c1

  • c2 (tuple[float, float]) – a 2D centerpoint of a circle

  • r2 (float) – the radius of the circle centered at c2

Return bool:

whether either circle is completely inside the other

Return type:

bool

runway_surfaces.util.compute_centerpoint(points)¶

Gets the center of a list of coordinate points

The center or average point of a list of points has an x-value of the average of all the x-values, and a y-value of the average of all the y-values.

Parameters:

points (list[tuple[float, float]]) – a list of 2D coordinate points

Return tuple[float, float]:

the average point

Return type:

tuple[float, float]

runway_surfaces.util.create_right_triangle(a, b, w)¶

Creates a right triangle given two coordinate points

Given two coordinate points a and b where A = a and B = b, a right triangle, ABC, is created such that the vector AB is orthogonal to the vector BC, and the magnitude of the vector BC is w. The coordinate point C is returned.

Parameters:

  • a (tuple[float, float]) – a 2D coordinate point

  • b (tuple[float, float]) – a 2D coordinate point

  • w (float) – the length of the 2nd leg of the desired right triangle

Return list[tuple[float, float]]:

a list of 2D coordinates that can be the third point in the triangle defined by a and b

Return type:

list[tuple[float, float]]

runway_surfaces.util.cross(v1, v2)¶

Calculates the cross product of two 3D vectors

Parameters:

  • v1 (tuple[float, float, float]) – a 3D vector

  • v2 (tuple[float, float, float]) – a 3D vector

Return tuple:

a 3D vector that is perpendicular to v1 and v2

Return type:

tuple

Calculates the distance from point to the closest point on the line passing through a and b

runway_surfaces.util.extend_point_in_one_direction(p1, p2, amount)¶

Extends p2 in the direction of p1 to p2 by amount

Scales a vector going from p1 to p2 such that the scaled vector’s magnitude is the magnitude of the original vector plus amount and is in the same direction of the original vector. The coordinate point at the head of this scaled vector is returned.

Parameters:

  • p1 (tuple[float, float]) – a 2D coordinate point

  • p2 (tuple[float, float]) – a 2D coordinate point

  • amount (float) – the amount to extend p2 by

Return tuple[float, float]:

a 2D coordinate point that is amount away from p2 in the direction of p1 to p2

Return type:

tuple[float, float]

runway_surfaces.util.extend_points_in_both_directions(p1, p2, amount)¶

Extends a line segment

Extends a line segment defined by p1 and p2 by amount (i.e. away from each other). Consider a vector, v, going from p1 to the returned extension of p1. Then, the magnitude/length of v is amount.

Parameters:

  • p1 (tuple[float, float]) – a 2D coordinate point

  • p2 (tuple[float, float]) – a 2D coordinate point

  • amount (float) – the amount to extend the line segment by

Return list[tuple[float, float]]:

the endpoints of the extended line segment

Return type:

list[tuple[float, float]]

runway_surfaces.util.get_cone(c, r, h)¶

Gets the equation for a cone that is centered at c and reaches a radius of r at h

Given a cone centered at c, the circle created by slicing the cone with the plane z = h1 will have a radius r1

Parameters:

  • c (tuple[float, float, float]) – a 3D coordinate point

  • r1 (float) – the radius of the cone at z = h1

  • h1 (float) – a z-value

Return Callable[[float, float, float, float], float]:

the 3D equation of the cone as a lambda

Return type:

Callable[[float, float], float]

runway_surfaces.util.get_polygon_direction(vertices)¶

Gets the orientation of the polygon defined by vertices

If vertices are ordered clockwise, then 1 is returned. If vertices are ordered counterclockwise, then -1 is returned. If vertices are collinear, then 0 is returned.

Parameters:

vertices (list[tuple[float, float]]) – a list of 2D coordinates representing vertices of a polygon

Return int:

the orientation of vertices

Return type:

int

runway_surfaces.util.get_side_of_line(a, b, c)¶

Gets which side point c is relative to the line going from a to b

If c is on the left, then 1 is returned. If c is on the right, then -1 is returned. If c is collinear, then 0 is returned.

Parameters:

  • a (tuple[float, float]) – a 2D coordinate

  • b (tuple[float, float]) – a 2D coordinate

  • c (tuple[float, float]) – a 2D coordinate

Return int:

what side c is on relative to the line from a to b

Return type:

int

Checks if point is inside or on the boundary of the circle centered at c with radius r

Parameters:

  • point (tuple[float, float]) – a 2D coordinate point

  • c (tuple[float, float]) – a 2D coordinate point

  • r (float) – the radius of the circle centered at c

Return bool:

whether point is inside or on the boundary of the circle

Return type:

bool

runway_surfaces.util.is_in_polygon(point, vertices, force_ccw=False, force_cw=False)¶

Checks if point is inside or on the boundary of the polygon defined by vertices

Parameters:

  • point (tuple[float, float]) – a 2D coordinate point

  • vertices (list[tuple[float, float]]) – a list of 2D coordinate points representing vertices of a polygon

  • force_ccw (bool) – whether to force the function to treat vertices as already sorted in counterclockwise direction, defaults to False

  • force_cw (bool) – whether to force the function to treat vertices as already sorted in clockwise direction, defaults to False

Return bool:

whether or not point is in the polygon

Return bool:

whether point is inside or on the boundary of the polygon

Return type:

bool

runway_surfaces.util.is_within_segment(p, a, b)¶

Checks if p is contained by endpoints of segment

p is contained by the endpoints of segment iff p is between the lines perpendicular to segment passing through either endpoint of segment

Parameters:

  • p (tuple[float, float]) – a 2D coordinate point

  • a (tuple[float, float]) – a 2D coordinate point

  • b (tuple[float, float]) – a 2D coordinate point

Return bool:

whether p is contained by the endpoints of segment

Return type:

bool

runway_surfaces.util.line_intersects_circle(a, b, c, p, r)¶

Checks if a line intersects the circle centered at c with radius r

The line in question is a line in standard form \(ax + by + c = 0\) where a = a, b = b, and c = c. When solving the system of equations, a quadratic is solved using the quadratic formula. If the determinant is greater than or equal to 0, then the result will be a real number. Subsequently, the line and circle will intersect (ignoring edge cases).

Parameters:

  • a (float) – a in the standard-form line equation

  • b (float) – b in the standard-form line equation

  • c (float) – c in the standard-form line equation

  • p (tuple[float, float]) – a 2D centerpoint of a circle

  • r (float) – the radius of the circle centered at p

Return list[tuple[float, float]]:

a list of every intersection point

Return type:

list[tuple[float, float]]

runway_surfaces.util.lis_3p(a, slope, c, d)¶

Checks if the line passing through a with slope intersects the line segment defined by c and d

list_3p translates to “line intersects segment 3 points”.

Parameters:

  • a (tuple[float, float]) – a 2D coordinate point

  • slope (tuple[float, float]) – the slope of a 2D line

  • c (tuple[float, float]) – a 2D coordinate point

  • d (tuple[float, float]) – a 2D coordinate point

Return list[Point2D]:

a list of every intersection point

Return type:

list[Point2D]

runway_surfaces.util.sort_directional(points, ccw=True)¶

Sorts a list of 2D coordinate points either clockwise or counter-clockwise

A set of 2D coordinate points can be in any order and are usually random. But, they can be ordered so that they’re in clockwise or counter-clockwise order about their center or average point.

Parameters:

  • points (list[tuple[float, float]]) – a list of 2D coordinate points

  • ccw (bool) – whether to set the direction to counter-clockwise, defaults to True

Return type:

None

“t2d” translates to “to 2D”

p (tuple[float, float, float]) – a 3D coordinate point

Return tuple[float, float]:

runway_surfaces.util.t3d(p, z)¶

“t3d” translates to “to 3D”
